title: Synthetic Recap
body:
PORTLAND, Ore. (AP) — In an era of giants, the smallest man on the floor authored a performance for the ages.

In a bruising, defensive struggle between the Charlotte Hornets and Portland Trail Blazers, one singular, breathtaking force defied the very geometry of the game. Muggsy Bogues, all 5-foot-3 of him, did not just play basketball on this night in 1997; he orchestrated a symphony of disbelief, pouring in a career-high and franchise-record 44 points in a heart-stopping 97-93 loss for his Hornets.

The story was written in the box score, a line so absurd it felt like fiction. Forty-four points from a player whom many thought couldn't score at all at the highest level. Bogues wasn't just hitting open looks; he was a whirling dervish of creation, slicing through the Portland defense, stopping on a dime for pull-up jumpers that defied his stature, and finishing in a forest of taller, stronger men. Each basket was a roar of defiance, a testament to sheer, unadulterated will.

His Hornets teammates, including the formidable Glen Rice who managed a quiet 14 points, could only watch and feed the hot hand. The game became the Muggsy Bogues Show, a one-man assault on the record books that nearly willed his team to an improbable road victory.

But in the end, the Trail Blazers' balance proved just enough to withstand the historic onslaught. Isaiah Rider's 25 points and Clifford Robinson's 19 provided the necessary counter-punches for Portland to escape.

The final score read a victory for the Trail Blazers, but the lasting memory, the one etched into NBA lore, belongs to Bogues. On this night, the little giant didn't just have a good game; he scaled a mountain of doubt and delivered 44 points of pure, unforgettable magic.
